I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Maldives has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for 
technical assistance (TA) to develop the capacity of the Maldives Energy Authority (MEA). The 
strengthening of the institutional framework in the energy sector is one of the key objectives of 
the government’s Strategic Action Plan for 2009–2013.  
 
2.  A fact-finding mission in September 2011 reached agreement with the government on 
the  purpose,  outputs,  methodology  and  key  activities,  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The Maldives has achieved the goal of 100% electrification, with all inhabited islands 
receiving electricity through diesel-based generators. The Maldives has among the highest 
power generation costs in South Asia currently averaging in excess of $0.30 per kilowatt-hour, 
several times higher than those of some other countries in the region.2 Petroleum-based fuels 
are a major import in the Maldives, with the country almost entirely dependent on these imports 
for power generation. Fuel imports comprise nearly 16% of the country’s gross domestic product 
and this has resulted in the Maldives facing the impact of significant fluctuations in international 
fuel prices. 
 
4.  Given international volatility in fossil fuel prices and increasing concerns about energy 
security and climate change mitigation, the government has pledged to be carbon neutral by 
2020. Since the energy sector has a key role to play in achieving this goal, the Ministry of 
Housing and Environment (MHE) formulated the Maldives National Energy Policy & Strategy in 
October 2010. Its objectives are to (i) provide all citizens with access to reliable and sustainable 
energy services at the lowest possible cost; (ii) achieve carbon neutrality in the energy sector by 
2020; (iii) promote energy conservation and energy efficiency; and (iv) increase national energy 
security. 
 
5.  With the announcement of the carbon neutral goal and an expected transition towards 
clean  sources  of  fuel,3 significant  investment  is  envisaged  in  the  electricity  sector  of  the 
Maldives by 2020. The Maldives is also one of the two Asian countries selected for the Scaling 
Up Renewable Energy Program (SREP).4 It is expected that concessional climate funds routed 
through the multilateral development banks would increase private sector financing to support 
investments  in  the  Maldives,  particularly  in  renewable  energy  (mainly  solar)  and  energy 
efficiency. A significant concern from the perspective of a long-term investor would be the 
presence of a well-defined and predictable regulatory regime. 
 
6.  MEA has been functioning for years under Presidential decree. It has the mandate to 
regulate the energy sector, advise the government on the energy sector, issue licenses to

on the energy sector. MEA’s functioning has been constrained by the lack of staff, finances, and 
a clear demarcation of roles and responsibilities. 
 
7.  Significant changes in the sector’s institutional structure have taken place over the last 3 
years including the reorganization of STELCO, the state-owned electricity utility responsible for 
power supply in Malé and nearby islands. There are now seven regional utilities operating 
across the Maldives and the island development committees5 have been gradually absorbed 
within these regional utilities. Utilities, especially the newly formed ones, have reiterated the 
need for timely guidance on technical, quality, and financial matters from MEA as they seek to 
meet their obligations. These and other changes necessitate the immediate development of 
appropriate regulations as well as the capacity building of MEA to regulate the sector in this 
transition period. 
 
8.  The  most  important  priorities  to  foster  greater  investment  in  the  energy  sector,  in 
particular  in  renewable  energy  and  energy  efficiency,  are  better  technical,  licensing,  and 
financial  regulations.  The  introduction  of  new  technologies  and  innovative  financing 
arrangements will require the presence of adequate and functional regulatory oversight in areas 
such as investment planning and contracting for utilities. This TA will address these priority 
requirements and the capacity building needs in MEA. 
 
9.  In October 2011, the World Bank announced support of $200,000 for the MEA. This 
support is expected to cover governance arrangements, review of existing power purchase 
agreements, development of the technical regulatory framework, standards of performance, and 
demand-side energy efficiency regulations. It will also cover the drafting of an institutional 
development plan. This support, which is expected to commence in 2011, will complement this 
ADB TA. An investment framework has been approved by the cabinet to support renewable 
energy investments. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be the development of an effective regulatory environment for 
the delivery of affordable, reliable, and clean energy. The performance measures will be the 
establishment  of  a  regulatory  framework  that facilitates increased interest  from the  private 
sector  in  the  energy  sector  by  2016  and  the  reduction  in  emissions  per  unit  of  power 
consumption of at least 20% by 2016. The outcome of the TA will be the enhanced capacity of 
the regulator to support the energy sector objectives. The performance measure will be the 
development of key regulations for the energy sector and capacity building for the regulator and 
utilities. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The outputs of the TA comprise the following: (i) development of key licensing and 
technical regulations; (ii) capacity building activities undertaken for MEA; (iii) development of a 
compliance framework for licensees; and (iv) support for energy efficiency and solar programs. 
                                                 
5 Island Development Committees have traditionally been responsible for operation of the power-house and supply of 
electricity to consumers on islands. Regional utilities have taken over this role on most islands.

3
The outcome can be achieved through adequate and timely support from MHE, MEA, the 
Renewable Energy Investment Office and the licensees. 
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The Government of Maldives has requested ADB to finance $400,000 equivalent. The 
TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). 
The  government  will  provide  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office  facilities, 
administrative  support,  and  other  expenses.  The  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan  are  in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  MHE will be the executing agency. A steering group headed by MHE and comprising 
representatives from MHE, MEA, and other agencies will be created to support implementation 
of the TA. MHE will also coordinate with stakeholders, including other ministries, utilities, large 
consumers, prospective investors, and consumer representatives, to receive their inputs on the 
TA activities. 
 
14.  The TA will require the services of 4 international consultants and 1 national consultant 
for a total of 14 person-months of consulting services. The international consultants will be: (i) a 
regulatory specialist and team leader (5 person-months), (ii) a technical specialist (4 person-
months),  (iii)  an  energy  efficiency  specialist  (1  person-month),  and  (iv)  a  solar  program 
specialist  (1  person-month).  The  national  consultant,  will  be  the  consultant  coordinator  (3 
person-months).  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for  consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  The 
consultants  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements under the TA will be done in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented from December 2011 to January 2014. Draft reports will be 
submitted by consultants and these will be finalized in discussions with MEA. Monthly progress 
reports will be submitted to MHE and ADB to ensure appropriate monitoring and evaluation. 
Good practices and lessons learned through the TA will be disseminated through workshops 
and the internet. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Maldives for Capacity Development of the Maldives Energy Authority 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8         Appendix 3   
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will recruit consultants to support the Ministry of 
Housing and Environment (MHE) and the Maldives Energy Authority (MEA) to assist with the 
activities that have been accorded priority for the electricity sector in the Maldives. The technical 
assistance (TA) will require the services of 4 international consultants for up to 11 person-
months and 1 national consultant for up to 3 person-months. The consultants will be recruited 
as individual consultants either directly or through a firm. They will be engaged in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA 
is expected to be implemented from December 2011 to January 2014. 
 
B.  Scope of Work 
 
 
1.  Regulatory Specialist  and Team Leader (international, up to 5 person-months 
over a 12-month period) 
2.  The regulatory specialist will assist MHE in reviewing existing tariff regulations, advise 
on  investment  planning  and  contractual  documents,  and  support  capacity  building  and 
compliance review at MEA. The specialist will prepare an inception report and work plan within 
2  weeks  of  commencing  the  assignment  after  discussions  with  the  MHE  and  MEA.  The 
specialist’s activities will include: 
 
3.  Task 1: Investment planning and contract review. The specialist will: 
(i)  Prepare guidelines (in coordination with MEA) for the development, submission, 
review, and periodic updates of load forecasts and least cost investment plans by 
the utilities on a periodic basis. 
(ii)  Develop a checklist (in coordination with MEA), covering technical, commercial, 
financial, and other aspects including the process to be followed, for a review of 
contractual documents such as power purchase agreements being entered into 
by utilities especially with regard to their impact on end-user tariffs and utilities’ 
investment plans. 
(iii)  Share  experiences  based  on  international  best  practices  in  regulatory 
environments similar to the Maldives. 
(iv)  Provide on-the-job training and conduct a workshop for utilities and MEA to 
address practical issues regarding submission and review of investment plans 
and key aspects of contractual documents. 
 
4.  Deliverables: (i) draft report of tasks 1 (i)–(ii) to be submitted by week 6; (ii) final report 
to be submitted after consultation with MEA and MHE; and (iii) on-the-job training and workshop 
to be held based on discussions with MEA. 
 
5.  Task 2: Tariff methodology. The specialist will: 
(i)  Develop a review paper on tariff methodology in the Maldives, based on a study 
of the historical financial performance of utilities, and suggest revisions to the 
existing tariff-setting methodology based on principles of cost recognition, cost 
recovery, and tariff setting.  
(ii)  Recommend changes to existing regulations, procedures, manuals, and financial 
models. These may be implemented under the TA in discussion with MHE.

Appendix 3  9 
(iii)  Provide capacity building on tariff methodology and financial reporting, including 
by sharing with MEA staff and licensees the international best practices followed 
by other similarly placed regulatory bodies. 
 
6.  Deliverables:  (i)  draft  report  of  tasks  1  (i)–(ii)  to  be  submitted  by  week  10;  (ii) 
presentation to MEA and licensee staff; and (iii) final report to be prepared in discussion with 
MEA. 
 
7.  Task 3: MEA capacity building program. The specialist will: 
(i)  In discussions with stakeholders (particularly MEA, MHE, and licensees) and in 
consultation with the technical consultant working under this TA, review and 
provide inputs to MEA’s draft institutional development plan. 
(ii)  Identify specific components of the institutional development plan that could be 
financed  under  the  TA  including  participation  in  regional  regulatory  bodies, 
exchange  programs  with  other  regulators,  and  short-term  regulatory  training 
courses. 
(iii)  In consultation with the technical consultant, review options to use the resource 
pool  of  licensed  power  engineering  workers  and  utilities  in  the  Maldives  to 
undertake some of the current tasks performed by a capacity constrained MEA 
(e.g., reviews of technical drawings, inspection activities) and identify MEA‘s 
oversight role for such tasks. 
(iv)  Working with the consultant coordinator, help MEA and utility staff implement the 
capacity building activities recommended and approved under the TA. 
 
8.  Deliverables: (i) draft capacity development review report by week 18; (ii) final report to 
be submitted after consultation with MEA and MHE; and (iii) implementation support to be 
provided on an intermittent basis, as needed. 
 
9.  Task 4: Compliance monitoring support for MEA. The specialist will: 
(i)  Review MEA’s compliance review framework to monitor the regulatory process 
and the functioning of MEA and regulated entities, and, in consultation with the 
technical specialist, suggest suitable key performance indicators that could be 
monitored on a periodic basis. 
(ii)  Help  MEA  develop  a  roadmap  (including  identifying  investment  and  human 
resource requirements) to implement this review framework. 
(iii)  Identify the roles and responsibilities of MEA personnel (and of counterpart staff 
in the regulated entities) to monitor the compliance review framework and data 
submission for calculation of the key performance indicators. 
(iv)  Conduct  a  workshop  to  present  the  review  framework  and  compliance 
requirements to regulated entities, and support implementation in discussion with 
MHE. 
 
10.  Deliverables: (i) draft report of tasks 4 (i)–(iii) to be submitted by week 26; (ii) final report 
to be submitted after consultation with MEA; and (iii) workshop to be held based on discussions 
with MEA. 
 
11.  The consultant must have a degree in finance or economics or engineering or law with at 
least  15  years  of  experience  in  the  energy  sector,  preferably  on  the  financial  aspects  of 
electricity sector regulations, as well as broader regulatory experience. He or she should have 
good planning, interpersonal, coordination, and writing skills, and should have experience of 
either  working  directly  with  or  giving  consulting  advice  to  the  highest  levels  of  regulatory

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
agencies and government. He or she should preferably have experience of leading and/or 
implementing similar assignments in small island countries or in ADB’s developing member 
countries (DMCs). 
 
2.  Technical  Specialist  (international, up to 4 person-months over an 8-month 
period) 
12.  The technical specialist will develop priority energy sector technical regulations, review 
existing regulations and guidelines, and develop capacity within MEA. The technical specialist 
will coordinate on certain activities with the team leader and will provide required support and 
information in a timely manner for preparation of reports. The technical specialist will prepare an 
inception report and work plan within 2 weeks of commencing the assignment after discussions 
with MHE and MEA.  The specialist’s activities will include: 
 
13.  Task 1: Review and development of key licensing and technical regulations and 
guidelines. The specialist will: 
(i)  Review the draft licensing framework and existing registration, licensing and 
technical regulations, as well as the various technical guidelines, procedures, 
and codes issued by MEA, and identify any gaps that need to be filled to ensure 
that the regulator functions effectively. 
(ii)  In  consultation  with  stakeholders,  particularly  MEA  and  regulated  utilities, 
propose appropriate modifications to existing regulations, guidelines, procedures, 
and codes, and, where required, draft new ones. 
(iii)  Provide  capacity  building  support  to  MEA  and  regulated entities  on relevant 
aspects  of  licensing  and  technical  regulations  to  enhance  effectiveness  and  
compliance. 
 
14.  Deliverables: (i) draft report of task 1 (i) to be provided to MEA by week 6; (ii) report on 
task 1 (ii) to be submitted after discussion with MEA;  
 
15.  Task 2: Licensing of power engineering workers. The specialist will: 
(i)  Review the proposed licensing framework for power engineering workers as well 
as  the  regulations  on  licensing  categories,  prerequisites  for  licensing,  and 
process for approval and renewal of licenses in the Maldives in light of changes 
in technology, sector structure, and key themes of the Maldives National Energy 
Policy & Strategy, 2010. 
(ii)  In discussions with stakeholders (particularly MEA, MHE, licensed workers, and 
the entities using the services of such licensed workers), review the performance 
of the licensed power engineering workers and identify additional work areas for 
which technical expertise will be required in the Maldives (including in the area of 
renewable energy and energy efficiency). 
(iii)  In discussions with the regulatory specialist, review available certification and 
testing options for such workers and make recommendations to MEA to enhance 
the skills of licensed workers in carrying out the required activities. 
(iv)  In consultation with MEA, suggest appropriate changes to the regulations based 
on the above assessment. 
(v)  Conduct a workshop to present the findings of the licensing framework review to 
stakeholders and discuss recommendations. 
(vi)  Help MEA implement the TA.

16.  Deliverables:  (i)  draft  report  of  tasks  2  (i)–(iv)  to  be  submitted  by  week  18;  (ii)  a 
workshop on the licensing framework; and (iii) final report to be submitted after discussion with 
MEA. 
 
17.  The consultant must have a degree in engineering with at least 15 years of experience in 
the energy sector, preferably on technical and regulatory aspects. He or she should have good 
planning,  interpersonal,  coordination  and  writing  skills.  He  or  she  should  preferably  have 
experience of leading and/or implementing similar assignments in small island countries or 
ADB’s DMCs. 
 
3.  Energy  Efficiency  Specialist  (international, 1 person-month over a 3-month 
period) 
18.  The energy efficiency specialist will assist MEA in reviewing possible energy efficiency 
and  load  shifting  measures  suitable  for  implementation  in  the  Maldives  through  various 
regulatory  measures.  The  specialist  will  coordinate  with  the  team  leader  and  will  provide 
required  support  and  information  in  a  timely  manner  for  preparation  of  any  reports.  The 
specialist will prepare an inception report and work plan within 1.5 weeks of commencing the 
assignment after discussions with MHE and MEA. 
 
19.  The specialist will: 
(i)  Review available studies conducted by utilities and other international agencies 
in  the  Maldives  on  the  potential  for  both  supply-  and  demand-side  energy 
management as well as the potential for load shifting. 
(ii)  Assist  MHE,  MEA,  and  utilities  in  assessing  various  policy  and  regulatory 
initiatives  to  support  practical  energy  management  measures  that  could  be 
readily implemented in the Maldives. This could include possible fiscal incentives, 
obligations,  white  certificates,  efficiency  standards,  labeling  of  electrical 
appliances, tariff structuring. 
(iii)  Make draft recommendations on shortlisted policy and regulatory options as well 
as any pilot programs that may be considered by MHE and MEA. 
(iv)  Conduct a stakeholder workshop on energy management and evaluate policy 
and regulatory options. 
(v)  In  discussions  with  MEA,  assist  in  the  development  of  draft  regulations  to 
encourage licensees and customers and of pilot implementation schemes to 
implement such measures. 
20.  Deliverables: (i) draft report of tasks (i)–(iii) to be submitted by week 6; (ii) a workshop 
to be held in consultation with MHE and MEA; and (iii) final report including task (v) to be 
submitted after the workshop in discussion with MEA. 
 
21.  The consultant must have a degree in engineering or economics with at least 10 years of  
experience in the energy sector. He or she should preferably have experience of leading or  
implementing similar energy efficiency projects in small island countries or ADB’s DMCs. 
 
4.  Solar Program Specialist (international, 1 person-month over a 3-month period) 
22.  The solar program specialist will assist MEA in undertaking the required steps to support 
the roll-out of a solar program in the Maldives. The specialist will coordinate with the team 
leader and provide the required support and information in a timely manner for the preparation 
of reports. The specialist will prepare an inception report and work plan within 1.5 weeks of 
commencing the assignment after discussions with MHE and MEA.

23.  The activities under these include but are not limited to 
(i)  Discuss with utilities, MHE, Renewable Energy Investment Office, as well as 
other stakeholders the potential for a solar program for Greater Male as well as 
Outer Islands and review available studies on the subject. 
(ii)  Advise MEA and MHE on the various prerequisites that need to be put in place to 
implement such a program. 
(iii)  Review relevant policies, tariff arrangements, codes, regulations, and guidelines 
from the perspective of supporting solar power development in the Maldives, and 
submit a draft report to MEA and MHE. 
(iv)  Conduct a stakeholder workshop on the above and, based on feedback received 
and relevant international experience, make refinements to the draft report. 
(v)  Provide any additional implementation support (to be discussed with MHE and 
MEA) on the solar program. 
 
24.  Deliverables: (i) draft report of tasks (i)–(iii) to be submitted by week 6; (ii) a workshop 
to be held in consultation with MHE and MEA; and (iii) final report to be submitted following 
discussions with MEA. 
 
25.  The consultant must have a degree in engineering or economics with at least 10 years of  
experience in the energy sector. He or she should preferably have experience of leading and/or 
implementing similar projects to support solar power development in small island countries or 
ADB’s DMCs.  
 
5.  Consultant  Coordinator  (national,  up  to  3  person-months  over  a  24-month 
period) 
26.  The consultant coordinator will be recruited for a period of 3 person-months to assist the 
international consultants with the logistical aspects of interfacing with utilities, MHE and MEA, 
and conducting workshops. The consultant must have a degree with at least 10 years of 
experience in the energy or other infrastructure sector. He or she should preferably have 
experience of working on similar projects with development agencies. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
 
27.  The reports to be produced at key stages of TA implementation have been specified in 
the terms of reference. Each consultant will prepare an inception report soon after commencing 
the assignment. Monthly progress reports are to be submitted to the Ministry and ADB. The 
consultants will submit three copies of the final report to ADB in English.
